newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela PdVSA dividends seen half of last year's.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela PdVSA dividends seen half of last year's.

text.p: Venezuelan state oil giant PdVSA expects this year's oil dividend -- paid to its only shareholder, the Venezuelan state -- will be less than half last year's one trillion bolivar ($2 billion) payment, a senior PdVSA official said.

"We're not going to have the same year as last when there was a devaluation and high oil prices," PdVSA vice president Luis Urdaneta told reporters. Devaluations increase bolivar revenues from PdVSA's dollar denominated oil sales.

PdVSA recently increased its 1996 dividend, to be paid this year, by 200 billion bolivars to one trillion -- but much of that increase will be used to pay down some of the 648 billion bolivars in tax refunds owed by the government to PdVSA.
"We expect the increased dividend will be compensated for by deducting the amount from the taxes we are owed," said Urdaneta.

The dividends do not include other payments that PdVSA makes to the treasury, which totaled four trillion bolivars last year - - over 10 percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and around half of total government revenues.
The reduced 1997 dividend comes as the government try to square its fiscal accounts for the year.

Finance Minister Luis Raul Matos Azocar said Thursday the year would close with a fiscal surplus equivalent to 1.6 percent of GDP. But the assertion was immediately disputed by opposition parties due to recent additional spending requests.
